subject: Sleep
title: Seasonal Patterns in Bipolar
description: A quick, practical guide to Seasonal Patterns in Bipolar.

hook.text: Spring brings mania. Winter brings depression. For many bipolar patients, seasons control their moods.

buildup.text: Seasonal light changes directly affect circadian rhythm length and melatonin production.

discovery.text: Longer spring days suppress melatonin and advance the clock, potentially triggering hypomania or mania.

twist.text: Shorter winter days do the opposite, extending melatonin duration and pushing the system toward depression.

climax.text: Managing light exposure proactively during seasonal transitions can help prevent mood episodes.

punchline.text: Bipolar moods follow the sun more closely than most people realize.

quiz.question: Why does spring sometimes trigger mania in bipolar patients?
options: Longer days suppress melatonin and advance the circadian clock
